addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord Highe Treasuro
r
of England.

19 N
o
1590
M
r
Bodeleie to my L./.

page.lettertext:
fol.226r
May it please yo
r
L. The pensioner, of whose
intent I advertised yo
r
L. the 28 of Oc
t
and
e 3 of No
v
is returned: who bringeth worde
for certaine, that there is no innovation in either
of those two places, that were specially noted in
e
plotte,
at I sent yo
w
. For he hath imploied a
man of purpose, to take a view of
e towne:
by whome he is informed, that
e fort only, and
e walle adjoining to it, w
ch
is marked in the
forsaid plotforme w
t
e letter M: w
ch
was also
that place, that was meant to be attempted by
those
at failed of their purpose, is better fortified.
Otherwise, saving that
e Garrison is somwhat
renforced, they have altered nothing in
e towne.
Moreover it hath fallen out very
happely, that
e other party, that is of
Zeland
, w
t
whome
e pensioner heere doth keepe correspondence,
(as I have written unto yo
w
in my former let-
ters) hath bin lately in
Piccardie
, uppon occa-
sion of buisnes, and hath mette there by chaunce,
w
t
one of his old acquaintance, an inhabitant at
this present, of
e towne afore signified, a man
very resolut, honest and religious: and one
that is usually there imploied about
e water
workes, specially those that appertene to
e passa-
ges through
e letter F. This man procee-
ded so farre, in communication about the
state of that towne, and
e weaknes therof in
sundrie places, that he gave to understand, if
it were to procure the libertie of his contrey,
he would revele as muche as he knewe of certaine
fol.226v
commodious entrances, and would not refuse
to hasard himself, w
t
any companies, that should
be sent by any Prince, to attempt
e surprise.
The other, notw
t
standing this insinuation made
unto him, by a speciall frind, and one that li-
veth in
e towne it self, thought it not behoofull
as then, to discover himself further, then in ge-
neral termes: so that then they departed, affected
both alike, but not resolving upon any thing.
Nevertheles he of Zeland doth build very muche,
upon
e good inclinac
o
n of
e said party, and
upon his meanes, to advaunce
e enterprise. For
whiche he hath sent me worde by
e pensioner,
at er it be long, he will be w
t
me at
e
Hage
,
to conferre of
e mater, and if I shall thinke
it good, he will make a voiage of purpose into
Piccardie, and send for his frind to come thither
unto him: w
t
whome he will enter into further
practise
as I shall advise him. Uppon this offer I doe
attend his comming, and thereafter as his re-
monstrance unto me, shall carie probablitie, I
will urge him, to goe seeke his frind, and to
worke so effectually w
t
him, as he maye be
interessed in
e action. I can not write of
this mater so plainely as I would, albeit it be
plainer, then I would willingly adventure, if
I had a cipher: whiche
yor
I trust yo
r
L. if
yo
w
finde it needefull, will send me with
e
soonest. Howbeit for mine owne endevo
rs
in
this mater, I hope to deale in suche sort, as ether
that whiche is intended, shall be thorowly effected,
fol.227r
or nothing undertaken to her
Ma
ties
prejudice.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. N
o
19 1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
